author: djrtwo
content:
It depends on the aggregation strategy. In a naive strategy, only best effort aggregations are broadcast at the end of a slot. The idea is the producer would then select from aggregates theyve received to pick the most profitable ones to include. That is, the attestations with the most not yet included participants. Good to note that the protocol lets you include duplicates so if you have two good attestations with some overlap but a lot of uniques, it could very well be worth including both. 

In more structured approaches to aggregation like Handel, the protocol aggregates stepwise in such a way to avoid overlaps entirely. 

Its important to note that a strategy in which all participants aggregate and rebroadcast the small aggregates as that go, will result in disorder -- tons of non-aggregable small attestations.

author: djrtwo
content:
Bls sigs can be combined in any linear combinations so if we allowed the protocol to remember how many of each attester was in each aggregate, then yoy could include duplicates. 

For example, if each attester was represented by two bits in the aggregate field, then you could aggregate your original example and flag the second validator as a double inclusion
